titleStmt.title: Walters Ms. W.313, Compilation of Rhymed Proverbs: Proverbs en rimes
Proverbs en rimes

respStmt.name: Walters Art Museum curatorial staff and researchers since 1934

availability.p: Licensed for use under Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported Access Rights, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/legalcode. It is requested that copies of any published articles based on the information in this data set be sent to the curator of manuscripts, The Walters Art Museum, 600 North Charles Street, Baltimore MD 21201.

notesStmt.note: This late fifteenth-century manuscript is one of the earliest surviving examples from a small group of illustrated compilations of proverbs. Each drawing and accompanying verse refer to a commonly known proverb or turn of phrase. The verse does not typically include the phrase, so the combination of image and text is like a riddle that would bring the saying to mind (the proverbs are used in this catalog record as the titles of the images). The proverbs can be both entertaining and moralizing, and they frequently refer to religious life, farming and trades, and acceptable (or unacceptable) behavior. This manuscript originally contained more entries, but several leaves were detached at some point or not included when the book was rebound. Two leaves separated from this manuscript are now in the Wildenstein Collection at the Musée Marmottan in Paris. A third individual leaf (fol.add.1), which has significant damage on one side, was purchased by the Walters Art Museum in the 1990s.

msContents.textLang: The primary language in this manuscript is French, Middle (ca.1400-1600).

support.p: Antique laid paper, medium-weight, moderate brown staining and worm holes; recurring watermark, usually truncated at spine edge, a male head in profile with flowing hair and a thin line ending in a star extending from the top of the head

supportDesc.foliation: Two sets of foliations, the first entered ca. 1900 on the lower right of rectos (fols. 1-71, 73-86, 81, 72, 87-91), the second (used here) entered ca. 1940 by Walters staff in upper right corners of rectos, and begins after fol. 71 to reflect current binding order; two leaves separated from this manuscript are now in the Wildenstein Collection at the Musée Marmottan in Paris; a third separated leaf (fol.add.1) was purchased by the Walters in the 1990s; flyleaves likely added by Léon Gruel in the nineteenth or twentieth century; watermark on front and back flyleaves, small heart flanked by "A" and "R" in an oblong outline; front flyleaf i,r and back flyleaf iii,v covered with crimson silk

p.formula: Due to tight binding, collation formula is unavailable

layoutDesc.layout: Written surface and lines varies from page to page

handDesc.handNote: Littera batarda cursiva by several scribes, capitals with large sweeping curves and extenders, lacking punctuation; some illustrations labeled with early cursive script by several different hands (e.g. "lange" on fol. 6v, "le fo[u]" on fol. 32r)

decoDesc.decoNote: Book has 182 pen drawings, with two additional images on separate leaf, in brown ink by three artists, shaded in fine hatching and occasional use of wash (fol. 3v), sparse use of red (fols. 14r and 55r) and green (fol. 79r); underdrawing in lead visible on several folios (e.g. fols. 31r, 60v, 71r); though executed in a simple fashion, the figures show animated facial expressions and gestures, and a variety of detailed interior and exterior scenes are used as backgrounds; two leaves separated from this manuscript are now in the Wildenstein Collection at the Musée Marmottan in Paris, a third separated leaf (fol.add.1) was purchased by the Walters Art Museum in the 1990s

decoNote.title: "When I keep most quiet, I am seen by one who gives no good counsel"
"To buy a pig in a poke"
"In the kingdom of the blind the one-eyed man is king"
"God is at the lending"
"The Devil is at the paying"
"If you wrestle with a collier, you will get a blotch"
"The big dog with the great collar"
"By shaving a fool one learns to shave"
"He who dares not cry out is beaten"
"Light gains make heavy purses"
"One hand washes the other"
"No flying without wings"
"You should not hang your cloak on a broken peg"
"You cannot hide behind a finger"
"The colt that does not break his halter is worth nothing"
"He that grasps at too much can hold on to little"
"He plants needles to grow bars"
"There is none so humpbacked in the parish that he cannot find a humpbacked wife"
"What the eye cannot see, the heart cannot regret"
"Link by link the coat of mail is finished at last"
"While the dog relieves himself, the wolf escapes to the woods"
"He sees two gods in one Mass"
"To bring a florin to nine groats"
"He cuts the stick with which he is beaten"
"A man must keep one eye on the woods and the other on the town"
"Brother Martin can sing only from his book"
"Once a woman's brow is broken, she becomes a wanton"
"Who speaks of the wolf finds him at the door"
"Largesse is stingy only toward man"
"An oven and a mill are nurseries of news"
"He is wise who is always on guard, for an enemy never sleeps"
"Embrace a churl and he will prick you"
"Prick a churl and he will embrace you"
"Don't look a gift horse in the mouth"
"Sick man, would you have health?"
"The more the mud is stirred, the more it will stink"
"The pitcher goes so often to the river that it is broken at last"
"I have no friend but my purse"
"He that reckons without his host must reckon twice"
"The gosling is unworthy to show the goose where to pasture"
"Goslings lead the goose to grass"
"After death the doctor is of no use"
"A sea voyage will teach you how to pray"
"He would bite the hand of a little child"
"Still waters run deep"
"An old cat does not need to have a straw dragged before it"
"Between two friends the spade is lost"
"Who keeps company with the wolf must learn to howl"
"A friend in need is a friend indeed"
"Who lives, sees"
"The caterpillar lives on the cabbage and the wise man on the fool"
"He who has a ready tongue will get to Rome"
"He ill conceals himself that shows his back"
"A handful of nobility is worth six pennies a year"
"He reaches with both hands and chews with both jaws"
"His vain and idle words are flutes in verjuice"
"A mighty knave will have a mighty fall"
"The Lombards' petitions for grace after meals consist of three dice on the table"
"To agree like cat and dog"
"He who has no ox lives from day to day"
"Piteous mothers make scurvy-ridden children"
"The face of a man has great power"
"After the feast the fool remains"
"There are all sorts of people in the world"
"It thunders until at last it rains"
"A prophet is not without honor save in his own country"
"He who makes crosetz makes lasaigne"
"A fool needs no bell"
"He is sure of a cat that has her skin"
"Too much urging makes a horse restive"
"Even the best singing can be too much"
"He's a poor guardian of honey who does not lick his own fingers"
"Large fish are not caught in small streams"
"There is no ascent so great but that the descent is equally so"
"All things are at length discovered in raking"
"He plucks out good herbs and plants bad"
"The wolf knows what the evil beast thinks"
"He who kicks against a prick deserves to be twice hurt"
"Who loves God loves his saints"
"It is wise not to live too high because of the crows, nor too low because of the foxes"
"A small pack is fit for a small peddler"
"Little by little the ox may catch the hare"
"He lives so wisely that he does not gamble, drink, nor give pledges, and yet some other misfortune overtakes him"
"Great clamor destroys the castle"
"The greedy man loves the wedding feast better than the bride"
"The knife should be chosen according to the meat"
"It is too late for the rat to repent when the cat has got it by the tail"
"No dog wants another dog in the kitchen"
"A rolling stone gathers no moss"
"God helps those who help themselves"
"All that glitters is not gold"
"Greedy folk do not care what they spend on their food"
"Ease makes the thief"
"All can be lost through carelessness"
"The cat would like to eat fish but will not get her feet wet"
"Who goes to Rome a fool returns a fool"
"If it has a beak, call it a sickle"
"There is a remedy for all things but death"
"Dress up a bush and it will seem a baron"
"A deaf man has no need for two Masses"
"A friend is better than money in the chest"
"He beats the bush while the others catch the birds"
"You cannot make a sparrow hawk of a buzzard"
"He eats cabbage with a spoon"
"He makes broth in a basket"
"The love of a great man is like the shadow of a bush"
"All rivers run to the sea"
"The mortar always smells of garlic"
"Strike while the iron is hot"
"Patience conquers great anger"
"He can pick new spoons out of an old house"
"Dame Loyalty sleeps and Truth is dead"
"Faith breaks the neck of him who bears her"
"Who washes an ass's head loses both labor and soap"
"He needs to have his ear pulled"
"He who has a bad neighbor has a bad morrow"
"Who turns the spit never tastes a morsel"
"He heats himself in his armor"
"Love lasts as long as the money holds out"
"Crooked loaves are made in the oven"
"In the oven of a lazy baker the dough freezes"
"Who would not resemble the wolf must not wear his hide"
"He ill protects himself who makes a coverlet of balls of yarn"
"It is well to beware of fools and children for they tell what they hear"
"Each priest praises his own relics"
"Go to the seashore to find your peer"
"A man wastes his worldly goods by seeking St. Peter at Rome and ignoring his presence at his door"
"He is not so much the devil as he is black"
"Finding a long tail on a false fox"
"Necessity is the mother of invention"
"Of a little take a little, of a mickle take a mickle"
"He carries fire in one hand and water in the other"
"He puts at his feet what he holds in his hands"
"Falling between two stools"
"Let sleeping dogs lie"
"If you carry a large bag, I carry the measure"
"I must make arrows of such wood as I have"
"He winnows his corn in the wind"
"A churl should have a churl's fare"
"An enterprising fool needs no wit"
"He leaps from cock to ass"
"A poor man supping cannot reach from one loaf to another"
"For want of a wise man, a fool is put in the pulpit"
"An ass finds nothing to eat in the hay-rack except thistles"
"The ass was beaten for performing another's task"
"He puts a stone before the scythe"
"To hunt a hare with a tabor (drum)"
"He who labors for another labors for himself"
"The wolf eats counted sheep"
"Let him that has no money in his purse have money in his mouth"
"It is useless to send a fool on an errand"
"It is good to have two strings to one's bow"
"There's many a slip between cup and lip"
"Who drives an ass and leads a whore hath toil and sorrow evermore"
"To beat the dog before the lion"
"The fool must have his club"
"He eats his grain in the blade"
"Such a cat is not to be caught without mittens"
"When there's a will there's a way"
"Sated pigeons find cherries bitter"
"From ill came the lamb, and to ill goes its skin"
"Men take oats or straw from debtors who are poor"
"The goat scratches the ground so much that it falls ill"
"He is called a rich pinart [selfish, unfriendly person]"
"Who has leisure makes a basket"
"The mule resembles its father"
"Carrying off either the foot or the wing of a bird"
"Let another take the snake from the bush"
"A man's esteem depends on his land"
"Coins that do not ring are found to be best"
"He is made to count the pegs"
"The house shows its owner"
"One knows a workman by his work"
"He sometimes laughs who bites"
"He that makes himself a sheep shall be eaten by the wolf"
"A foolish abbot runs a foolish ménage"
"Who cannot grind at one mill must go to another"
"If the shoe fits, wear it"
"To shoe the goose"
"He steps back in order to leap higher"
"Trickery turns upon its master"
"The sluggard loves to be done with his work"
"One must not cast pearls before swine"

note.p: The word "marguerites" in Middle French meant both "pearls" and "daisies"

decoNote.title: "A good wine needs no praise, and a poor one is not improved because of it"

binding.p: Rebound in France, twentieth century; crimson leather over boards sewn on five single cords; identical blind tooled design on front and back boards: rectangular sections of intertwining vines at sides and foliate squares at corners, central panel with two columns of three roundels (containing a pelican and chicks, a bird with two eggs, a baboon, a sheep, a feline, and a man) with two confronted dragons at top and bottom; six compartments at spine framed by thin blind tooled borders, "RECEUIL DE PROVERBES" in second compartment, "1470" in third compartment; gold line along board-edges; narrow crimson turn-ins; white parchment pastedowns bordered with three gold lines, stamped "GRUEL" in gold on front pastedown at bottom center; endbands in green, yellow, and red silk worked with edge-bead around two-tiered cord core; modern green silk ribbon marker and gilt edges added in nineteenth or twentieth century

history.provenance: Created in Savoy in the late 1480s
Notes in pencil, "12" on flyleaf iv, "XVᵉ / Le plus ancien connu" on flyleaf ii,r in nineteenth or twentieth century
Léon Gruel, Paris, late nineteenth or early twentieth century; Gruel collection number "12" in pencil on flyleaf iv; Gruel and Engelmann bookplate inscribed "No. 413"
Henry Walters, Baltimore, purchased from Gruel on February 17, 1906; receipt housed in museum archives
history.acquisition: Walters Art Museum, 1931, by Henry Walters' bequest
